node.text: The race between covid-19 vaccines and variants is on. Alok Jha, The Economist’s science correspondent, and Natasha Loder, our health policy editor, discuss what this means for the future. Cover image credit: Alamy

node.title: Covid-19: can vaccines keep up with variants?

node.text: The Taliban’s swift return to power in Afghanistan has shocked the world and humiliated America. What effect will this have on the international standing of the US and on global security? Our experts answer your questions. Cover credit: AP

node.title: Afghanistan: how the Taliban weakened America

node.text:
Most governments recognise that vaccination is the fastest way out of the pandemic, but in many places hesitancy is hindering the roll-out. Should employers—or even governments—force people to have the vaccine? We answer your questions.

Cover image credit:

node.text:
The covid-19 pandemic has reinforced humanity’s dependence on modern tech, but the same tools that enable remote working are also being used to spread disinformation and perpetuate cybercrime. Ambivalence towards technology is nothing new.

Cover image credit: Scott Strazzante/The San Francisco Chronicle via Getty Images

node.text:
More than 50 countries around the world have pledged to become net zero. But what does net zero actually mean—and is it achievable?

Cover image credit: Brandon Thibodeaux/ The New York Times / Redux / eyevine

node.text:
In the past couple of weeks South Africa has witnessed the worst violence since the end of apartheid in 1994. Our correspondent in Johannesburg explains what he has seen on the streets and why the country is in crisis. 

Cover credit: Getty Images

node.title: South Africa: what's behind the riots?

node.text:
In America, the intelligence services deem far-right extremism a greater domestic threat than Islamist terrorism. The pandemic has exacerbated the spread of white supremacism and neo-Nazism.

Cover image credit: Michael Nigro/Pacific Press/LightRocket via Getty Images

node.title: Fortnite to far right: the rise of digital extremism

node.text:
Across much of the world, covid-19 restrictions are starting to ease. The Economist has crunched the data to calculate how close countries are to pre-pandemic levels of normality—but will life ever be the same again? 

Click on the link in our bio to visit our website and explore our interactive normalcy tracker. It covers 50 countries which account for 76% of the world’s population and 90% of its GDP.

Cover image credit: Lluis Gene/AFP via Getty Images

node.title: Covid-19: why your life will never be the same again

node.text:
The world’s animals and wildlife are going extinct at a greater rate than at any time in human history. Can technology help turn the tide?

Cover image credit: Yashpal Rathore/Nature Picture Library

node.title: Mass extinction: what can stop it?

node.text: Bitcoin and other cryptocurrencies set out to upend the financial order and replace conventional money. Bitcoin has certainly disrupted the global financial system, but can it ever live up to the hype? Cover credit: Jakub Porzycki/Getty Images

node.title: Crypto: will the bitcoin dream succeed?

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on August 30, 2021. May be a cartoon of text that says 'Bartleby Why women should think twice before opting for more remote work OFFICE THE TOTHE'.

node.text:
It is a truth universally acknowledged that women carry a heavier burden than men when it comes to child care and household chores.⁠
⁠
The office can be a welcome break from never-ending duties such as housekeeping and parenting—but one pre-covid study on work-life balance also suggested that women were likelier than men to experience “flexibility stigma”.⁠
⁠
If more women are based at home, and take on an even greater share of family responsibilities, the result may be an ever-bigger gender pay gap and an ever-harder glass ceiling.⁠
⁠
Click the link in our bio to read why female employees should think twice before opting to work remotely.⁠
⁠
Illustration: @ilovechickenkiev

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on August 30, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and standing.

node.text:
Months before covid-19 had even been identified, Chinese officials warned that the spread of a deadly and highly transmissible virus was threatening the country’s economic stability and its people’s prosperity.⁠
⁠
They were referring to the virus that causes African swine fever. The disease is harmless to humans but deadly to the pigs that provide one of China's most important sources of food. ⁠
⁠
Many feel that China has been far less forthcoming about swine-fever cases than it has with covid-19 infections. “It seems like China can’t do for pigs what it did for people,” says an executive at a pig firm. ⁠
⁠
But tap the link in our bio to read how the Chinese government’s instinct is to use a similar tactic with the pig disease that it initially tried with the coronavirus: covering up. ⁠
⁠
Credit: Redux / eyevine

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on August 30, 2021. May be an image of 4 people and text that says 'Americas Democracy is quickly eroding in Central America'.

node.text:
Central American countries have long been dominated by small yet powerful political and economic elites that do not necessarily favour democracy. ⁠
⁠
Institutions that ought to uphold the rule of law, such as the courts and UN-backed bodies, have been co-opted or dismantled, allowing corruption to increase in El Salvador, Honduras and Guatemala, collectively known as the “Northern Triangle”, and Nicaragua. The pandemic has added to these problems.⁠
⁠
Some violence-reduction programmes may have had some success over the past few decades. But even assessments by USAID admit that past aid efforts have had little effect.⁠
⁠
Few ordinary folk in these countries think they can change things through elections or protests. Many think their only option is to flee from their homes.⁠
⁠
Tap on the link in our bio to read why things are looking grim in El Salvador, Honduras, Guatemala and Nicaragua. ⁠
⁠
Illustration: @klawerzeczy

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on August 30, 2021. May be an image of one or more people, street, road and text that says 'HAPPY MADARAKA DAY2021 HAPPY MADARAKA DAY 2021 Jelcome l KISUMU Welcomute KISUMU ylsilk 菇'.

node.text:
Breaking constitutions is often easier than making them. Kenya’s ﬁrst two presidents, Jomo Kenyatta and Daniel arap Moi, took a hatchet to the one negotiated at independence from Britain in 1963.⁠
⁠
Fixing the damage took decades. But in recent years the hatchets have been out again.⁠
⁠
Uhuru Kenyatta, Kenya's president, and Raila Odinga, his rival-turned-sidekick, hatched a plan to expand their executive power under the guise of their "Building Bridges Initiative". ⁠
⁠
Kenya's judges were quick to realise it was a stitch up, and this month the Court of Appeal thwarted the plan. ⁠
⁠
The judiciary has shown its mettle. The constitution has proved resilient—and is now harder for politicians to meddle with. Kenya's politicians, on the other hand, have been tarnished. Tap the link in our bio to find out more. ⁠
⁠
Credit: New York Times / Redux / eyevine

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on August 30, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'The number of child labourers has increased for the first time in 20 years Children in child abour* Selected regions, % of child population Sub-Saharan Africa 30 25 Asia and the Pacific 20 Latin America and the Caribbean 15 10 2008 12 *5- 5 17- year-olds 16 0 20 Source: "Child Labour: Global estimates 2020, trends and the road forward", ILO and UNICEF The Economist'.

node.text:
The sweetest chocolate can come from the most bitter of sources. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
In May police in Ivory Coast rescued 68 children working on cocoa farms, allegedly trafficked in from neighbouring Burkina Faso. They are a tiny share of the approximately 790,000 children working in cocoa production in Ivory Coast alone.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
A report by the International Labour Organisation and UNICEF reveals that some 160m—one in ten—of the world's children are engaged in labour, understood as work that they are too young to perform or that might harm their “health, safety or morals”. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Child labour fell in most parts of the world between 2000 and 2016, but that decline has levelled off—except in sub-Saharan Africa, where number of children working began to increase in 2012. Now 24% of children in the region work—four times the proportion in Latin America and the Caribbean.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
The rising numbers of Africa's poor—swollen by the pandemic—explain the change. To learn which policies could help mitigate the effects of covid-19 and poverty on child labour, tap the link in our bio.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on August 30, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'The number of child labourers has increased for the first time in 20 years Children in child abour* Selected regions, % of child population Sub-Saharan Africa 30 25 Asia and the Pacific 20 Latin America and the Caribbean 15 10 2008 12 *5- 5 17- year-olds 16 0 20 Source: "Child Labour: Global estimates 2020, trends and the road forward", ILO and UNICEF The Economist'.

Photo by The Economist on August 30, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'The number of child labourers has increased for the first time in 20 years Children in child abour* Number of children, m Rest of world 300 Latin America and the Caribbean 250 200 150 Asia and the Pacific 100 2008 Sub-Saharan Africa 12 50 *5- to 17- year-olds 16 0 20 Source: "Child Labour: Global estimates 2020, trends and the road forward", ILO and UNICEF The Economist'.
Photo by The Economist on August 30, 2021. May be an image of food.

node.text:
Four years ago Ibrahim El Kaakour gave up his engineering career abroad and returned to Lebanon to reinvigorate his family's olive groves. ⁠
⁠
His goal is to revive Lebanon's long-dormant olive-oil industry. He is not the only one with this dream.⁠
⁠
Walid Mushantaf converted wheat ﬁelds into olive groves in 2010. He now grows Italian olive varieties. Deeper in Lebanon’s mountains, Rose Bechara Perini grows the local souri variety on her extended family’s land. ⁠
⁠
They all face the same challenges, compounded by Lebanon's long-running financial and economic crisis. Tap the link in our bio to find out what they are. ⁠
⁠
Credit: Xinhua News Agency / eyevine

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on August 29, 2021. May be art of 1 person.

node.text:
Boris Johnson was a keen student of New Labour, whose era coincided with his own ascent to prominence.⁠
⁠
In the mid-1990s was repelled by the British party's “spin-driven vanilla-flavoured candyfloss nothingness”. But he was mesmerised, too, for Tony Blair was a winner.⁠
⁠
He observed how “Supertone” ransacked the Tory wardrobe, played the press “like a master organist” and imposed a new doctrine on his party.⁠
⁠
These days the two premiers seem to occupy opposite ends of the political landscape. But on the campaign trail and in the suburbs, the two men look more alike. ⁠
⁠
To find out what Tony taught Boris, tap the link in our bio.⁠
⁠
Illustration: @elliefp

buttons.text: Visit the COVID-19 Information Center for vaccine resources.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on August 29, 2021. May be an image of one or more people, military uniform and outdoors.

node.text:
The Delta variant has made Australia's zero-covid strategy untenable. ⁠
⁠
From now on covid-19 cases will be allowed to rise as long as hospitals can cope with them. ⁠
⁠
Repeated lockdowns are causing discontent in the country now that the rest of the world is opening up. ⁠
⁠
"This is not a sustainable way to live,” declared Scott Morrison, Australia’s prime minister, defending the dramatic shift in covid-19 strategy. ⁠
⁠
About a quarter of Australians are fully jabbed, compared with 50-60% of Europeans and Americans. And almost none have acquired immunity naturally, through infection.⁠
⁠
The plan is to drop most restrictions once 80% of adults are vaccinated, which looks achievable by the end of the year. ⁠
⁠
Click the link in bio to find out why other countries using the zero-covid model are in a similar Delta predicament. ⁠
⁠
Credit: AAP /Dan Himbrechts

node.text:
Is science denialism on the rise, or is it just getting more press? On our “Babbage” podcast, we ask Dr Lee McIntyre, author of “How to Talk to a Science Denier” and researcher at the Center for Philosophy and History of Science at Boston University, what can be done about this worrying trend.⁠
⁠
Also on the podcast, the 20th Century was a golden age for physics but some of its ideas for explaining the material universe have been thrown into doubt. ⁠
⁠
Could a theory known as entropic gravity usher in a new dawn? And, the impressive technology behind the next generation of prosthetic limbs.⁠
⁠
To learn more about the latest in science and technology, click the link in our bio to listen to “Babbage”

node.text:
President Joe Biden vowed retribution on an affiliate of Islamic State for two suicide-bombings at Kabul airport that killed dozens and injured many.⁠
⁠
“We will hunt you down and make you pay,” he said in a speech at the White House. ⁠
⁠
The attacks were carried out by Islamic State Khorasan Province, an enemy of both the Taliban and America. The events of this week in Afghanistan beg the question: where next for global jihad?⁠
⁠
Around the world, jihadists are inspired by the Taliban’s triumph. The ripple effects will be felt far and wide. It will fire up jihadists in other countries, and spur recruits to join their struggle. ⁠
⁠
What is the long-term solution? To find out, tap the link in our bio to read this week's cover story.⁠
⁠
Credit: The Economist/Shutterstock

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on August 29, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'The future of American power " If the United States can vanquish its demons, it can harness a new kind of global power Anne Marie Slaughter'.

node.text:
The grim images from Afghanistan highlight the limits of America’s military power and the mismatch between its goals and the tools available to achieve them, writes Anne-Marie Slaughter in The Economist. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Yet the future of American power depends less on military might than on the demographic change taking place within the United States, argues the chief executive of New America, a foundation in Washington, DC.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
“In the next two decades America will evolve from a white-majority nation into a ‘plurality nation’: a country in which no one racial or ethnic group holds a majority. America must either figure out how to harness the enormous benefits of reflecting and connecting the world, or allow demographic tensions to tear it apart,” she warns. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Tap the link in our bio to read why Ms Slaughter thinks America’s diversity is its strength.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Illustration: @dan.will

Photo by The Economist on August 29, 2021. May be an illustration of 1 person.
Photo by The Economist on August 29, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Science & Technology Physics seeks the future. But is supersymmetry dead?'.

node.text:
After finding the Higgs boson particle, the Large Hadron Collider embarked on its real purpose: to search for a phenomenon called Supersymmetry, or "Susy" for short.⁠
⁠
Supersymmetry is the vanguard of a deeper hypothesis, string theory, which would connect the fundmantal forces, and thus provide a so-called “theory of everything”.⁠
⁠
But 13 years after the LHC opened, none of the particles predicted by Supersymmetry have shown up. ⁠
⁠
Without supersymmetry, string theory looks pretty-much dead as a theory of everything. Scientists are getting worried that they aren't going to find it.⁠
⁠
But what has seemed one of physics’s darkest periods could be about to brighten into a new morning. Tap the link in our bio to discover why.⁠
⁠
Credit: @michael_marbles
